This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 So let's begin.
My name is Amit.
Thank you very much for having me.
I'm very happy to be here.
First time in Gdynia.
And today I'll present a new way to perform sandbox evasion, introducing VBA referencing
along the way.
And my key point in this presentation, I guess, is I want to introduce a new approach to sandbox
evasion, a new approach to detect a sandbox and a new approach to evade a sandbox.
And I think this is specifically relevant for this conference, as blue and red teams
have met together to discuss these topics.
So as I said, my name is Amit, and I'm from Tel Aviv, Israel.
Not Shin Bet, not Mossad.
I'm not lying to you.
I promise.
I work at Votiro as a security researcher, and I used to work for Checkpoint before that,
studying exploit kits.
And I like to skate, I used to skate, I swim, and I play the guitar.
And my co-researcher in this research is our CEO, Aviv, who couldn't be here today.
And as I said, we will be talking about sandboxes and sandbox evasion.
And the main motivation for this research was the fact that sandboxes have become so
widely used in the industry.
I mean, almost every organization has a sandbox nowadays, and it's trusted.
Which means if the file has passed the sandbox, the user quite usually thinks that the file
is safe and he can open it and no problem whatsoever.
And so we have sandbox evasion techniques, and I will show a new way.
And unlike common sandbox evasion techniques, what we came up with doesn't require code
execution at all.
So just to set things straight before we begin, I'm going to jump between topics and
I don't want to confuse anyone.
So if you see the icon of this little guy running, he's trying to evade something.
So this is relevant to evasion.
And we will talk about evasion techniques and VBA referencing in terms of evasion.
And if you see this magnifying glass, it's about detecting a sandbox.
And we'll talk about that in a sec.
Usually when we talk about a sandbox, the following topics might come to mind.
And I talk about Office and VBA as well.
And I won't be getting into any of these topics, but please feel free to contact me offline
or by email if you have any further questions.
So I won't be discussing in length VBA macros, visual basics for applications, or the Office
protected view as a general.
We won't talk about sandbox solutions and the general concept of a sandbox, and tracking
pixels.
So I'm guessing the audience is familiar with these topics.
If not, please feel free to contact me.
My details will be at the end of this presentation, and I'll be happy to answer.
So let's start with sandbox evasion techniques as they are today.
And at the beginning, there was just malware, right?
And everything was fine.
And then sandboxes have begun to be used in the industry, and malware authors have begun
to use sandbox evasion techniques.
And the term sandbox evasion usually is being used to describe every way you can to detect
or manipulate or evade or trick or whatever word you can come up for a malware to trying
to trick a sandbox.
And this is literally what happens when you use sandbox evasion.
It's either to detect the sandbox or evade it, or both.
So let's go over some of sandbox evasion techniques as they are being used today.
And I'm actually quoting a very good presentation from first conference in 2017.
It's called Countering Innovative Sandbox Evasion Techniques Used by Malware.
And we'll start with evasion, with detection, sorry, that's a mistake.
So usually sandboxes are virtualized products.
It's being used on incoming files on the inbound traffic to the organization in order to prevent
malicious files from entering the organization.
So you set up a virtualized environment, and you let the files execute in this environment.
So because it's a virtualized environment, I can look for virtualized artifacts.
I can look at the hypervisor and try to understand if it's a physical hypervisor or a virtual
one, for example, VMware or VirtualBox or this kind of hypervisor.
I can look for virtualizing DLLs.
If it's a virtualized product, it must have some drivers to support it, and so on.
Another thing I can use is side channel attacks.
I can figure in advance the CPU tick of a physical machine and compare it to the CPU
tick of the machine I'm currently at and compare those.
And if it's a virtualized machine, it should be different than the physical machine, and
so forth.
And another thing I can do is look at the hardware.
Does this hardware setup make sense?
If it's a genuine user machine, it makes no sense for it to have 20 gigs of disk space
or 2 gigs of RAM, because it's not so common today.
And in virtualized machines, it's actually quite common because you want to spare your
resources.
So that's number one.
And number two, I can look at the environment.
And I can say, OK, how artificial this environment is.
I mean, does it make sense?
Does it look like a genuine user's environment?
I can look at the username.
I can look at the recent file count and screen resolution.
Check the cookies and browser history, if they exist.
I can look at running processes and say, OK, if I encounter the Wireshark or process monitor
or process explorer, then this most likely is a security researcher trying to analyze
my malware.
And I don't want to infect this machine.
And one final thing that's really cool, actually, is looking for old vulnerabilities.
So I have my malware trying to exploit a very old vulnerability.
And if it succeeds, it means that this environment is vulnerable to a very old vulnerability,
which makes no sense if it's a user.
The user must have patched this vulnerability beforehand.
So this most likely an artificial environment used to test my malware.
And I don't want to infect this environment.
So these are all used for detection.
And we can actually see this tool called Paranoid Fish.
I'm guessing some of you know it.
It's used by security researchers to test their environment.
So you execute this code in your environment.
And it looks for some of the stuff that we've talked about.
It looks at the hypervisor and CPU.
It checks username, file path, mouse activity, and disk size, and so forth.
So this covers the detection part.
And we can move on to evasion, where I can analyze the product I'm trying to evade and
go around it.
For example, most sandboxes use hooks.
And if I know what those hooks are, I can either remove them altogether or walk around
them.
I can use different API calls or functions that are not hooked.
And I can delay execution, for example, using sleep.
But sleep is a known trick by now.
So I can count Fibonacci numbers and so on.
And another thing I can do is force user interaction or user behavior on a virtualized machine.
And I can say, OK, I want the malware to execute after three clicks on the GUI interface,
and so forth.
So I can require user interaction.
I can check the date and time zone to see if it makes sense.
Or if I can target my user according to the date and time, and encrypt payloads, and so
forth.
So this is pretty much for detection and evasion.
The thing about these techniques, which are being used today, is most of them require
code execution.
So I have to get my code running within the sandbox.
And then my code collects all sorts of data, trying to fingerprint the system.
And once it does, it can decide if it's a user or a sandbox, and then act accordingly.
If it's a sandbox, it will abort execution.
If it's a user, it will infect the machine.
And the thing is, sandboxes nowadays are able to identify sandbox evasion techniques.
So if I don't bother to obfuscate my code, static analysis tools can actually analyze
my code and say, OK, he's trying to do A, B, and C. It's a suspicious behavior.
I'm not going to even bother executing it.
It looks suspicious enough.
I'm going to block it.
And if I did obfuscate my code, so the sandbox, as a sandbox environment, will execute it
and analyze my behavior and say, OK, this is a suspicious behavior.
He's trying to fingerprint me.
I don't know what's going on.
I'm going to flag it as suspicious anyway.
So nowadays, we have sandboxes being able to detect sandbox evasion techniques.
And the process never ends.
Malware authors provide new sandbox evasion techniques.
Sandboxes block them.
And the wheel keeps on turning.
We try to produce a new way to perform sandbox evasion all together.
So, sorry, it feels like my bar mitzvah.
OK, so, VBA referencing.
VBA, Visual Basic for Application, it's a very known concept.
It's been used in the industry for a long time.
It's been developed since the 90s, I guess.
And it has all sorts of capabilities that most users are not aware of.
And in order to truly understand its capabilities, you have to read this document,
the MSO VBA document, which is not so nice.
It's the documentation by Office, 111 pages, and they update it every now and then.
And it details all the information you can, all the capabilities and features you have
within Visual Basic for Application.
So, VBA is actually a binary file.
It's a file format.
And if we talk in regards to Office products, we have the VBA project.bin,
which is a binary file embedded within Office files,
which provides the VBA capabilities.
So, we went and we looked in the MSO VBA, which was not that pleasant of a task,
but we did it.
And we were surprised to know that we were not actually the first one to look in this document.
Big surprise.
And Mr. Hay-Faily, I hope I pronounced it right, in his presentation,
the analysis of attack surface of Microsoft Office from a user perspective.
In this presentation, he details a very cool remote code execution,
because it appears that VBA projects can be pointed to automation type libraries,
which is, let's call it a DLL for a lack of a better name.
You can point your VBA project to this library.
It will be fetched and loaded, and it can actually get the execution flow.
And then, effectively, you get code execution.
So, this is what he had discovered.
And he details in his presentation the life of this vulnerability,
because it has been known for a while and Microsoft has decided not to fix it.
Once he was able to exploit it, Microsoft has decided to fix this.
So, we did the same.
We went into this document and we had a look around,
and we found something else that we found curious to us.
And it's actually references.
So, VBA, Visual Basic for Application, is based on Visual Basic.
And my guess is that Microsoft aimed to make VBA a sort of programming language
just like any other programming languages, and they can use referencing.
And so, why not have VBA use referencing as well?
So, this is this capability.
You can point your VBA project into a remote VBA project
and have it fetched and loaded, and then you can use its code as your own.
So, this is what it looks like.
This is the actual text from the MSO VBA document.
And this is what caught our eye.
You can actually provide a path.
Could be a local, relative, absolute, remote path.
And there's actually no questions asked.
I mean, no security.
You don't have to test for anything.
As long as it's available, it will be fetched and loaded,
and you can use its code as your own.
And we thought that this is quite interesting,
and we've decided to explore a little bit.
And we've begun doing some testing.
So, first of all, we went and tested Word, the Word processor,
which is heavily used in the industry.
It's a very good candidate for infection.
And we found out that it's not that reliable.
I'm aiming to produce a reliable attack,
something I can use without fear of it failing.

which is cool.
And then you get a weird prompt, and you get protected view again,
which shouldn't happen, and then nothing happens.
You can't really tell what's going on in this document.

OK, I can live with that, but it's not.
I mean, you cannot predict what's going on.
This is a completely different error.
You open the document, you get a prompt,
and after that, you'll have to disable protected view.
So, the thing is, I just cannot rely on Word to produce an attack.
And moving on, we have PowerPoint, the presentation program.

look, this document, we have identified some potentially dangerous elements within.
It tries to do something, and if I was a user,
I wouldn't open this document for myself.

and that's OK.

in this module.
So, VBA referencing works, it works very good for Excel,
and we will use it later on in this attack.
And the funny thing about Office is the fact that,
even though they were all developed in the same place, in Microsoft, in Office,
and they are under the same suit of products,
they have different divisions.
So, they have the Word division, they have PowerPoint division,
and they have Excel divisions.
And they all produce something different.
I don't know why, but you have Word and PowerPoint,
which doesn't act the same as Excel.
And I'm just going to rely on Excel for this attack.
So, what we have so far is sandbox evasion techniques require code execution.
And we have VBA referencing allowing us to fetch and reference code
from a different location.
And we will use this to craft an attack.
So, maybe some of you have already thought about it.
I can use VBA referencing to perform sandbox evasion, somewhat.
I can send a blank document, which has VBA markers inside,
and uses VBA referencing.
And so, no suspicious code in the document that I send,
and only suspicious code in the fetched document.
And this might work on some sandboxes,
but the thing is that eventually,
the fetched code will be executed within the sandbox,
and the sandbox will identify it, and you still end up in the same loop.
I mean, you have malicious code execution in the sandbox,
the sandbox will detect it.
And it leads to nowhere.
So, we thought, what if I can identify who's asking?
If it's a sandbox asking, I'll reply with a benign piece of code.
And if it's a user asking, I'll reply with a malicious piece of code.
And then, effectively, I'll have sandbox evasion.
But in order to do that, I have to detect the sandbox.
So, just a few notes on a sandbox before moving on.
Because sandboxes are so heavily used in the industry,
and they inspect each incoming file,
and this could be thousands or tens of thousands of files each day,
you have to apply a set of rules, these are logical rules,
to prevent the sandbox from clogging your network.
So, first of all, the sandbox has to be automatic.
I mean, no user interaction,
no tinkering or messing with it on the user side.
Once the file has ended up on the user end, it's safe.
You can use it, no worries whatsoever.
So, that's number one.
Number two, it has to be fast.
I mean, if you have a thousand files per day,
each file takes between five to ten minutes to being analyzed,
you will effectively clog your network.
So, besides setting a time limit,
sandbox vendors do all sorts of optimization,
whether it's the hardware optimization,
or on the OS level, or on the application level.
And the final thing, it has to be secure-less,
because a sandbox is called a sandbox
because nothing bad can happen within.
Everything you do within a sandbox won't affect your environment.
So, you can just say,
OK, I'm going to drop most or all of the security mitigations,
and I will allow the malware to execute freely,
and then I can see exactly what it tries to do as fast as I can,
and then I can flag it as fast as I can.
And I can actually, if I see what it's doing completely,
I can say, OK, it's this kind of malware family,
or that kind, and so forth.
And actually, the last bullet actually supports the two above,
because when you disable security mitigations,
you don't have to click enable content,
so the process is automatic, for example, and it's faster.
You don't have to load all of the security mitigations,
and you don't have to disable them, so it's quicker.
And building on top of that,
let's have a look at the difference between a sandbox and a user
in terms of Office.
So, when a user opens a document,
usually, by group policy, the user is protected with protected view,
which is a very good product.
I don't have anything bad to say about it, by the way.
And so, the user opens the document,
and he has to disable protected view
to allow all sorts of elements to be loaded in the document.

So, you have document open.
If you want to move along, disable protected view.
At some point, the VBA engine will load,

If we look at the sandbox,
because it's fast and automatic and secure,
we don't have protected view.
So, the document is opened,
and no protected view whatsoever
to support all of the bullet points we talked about.
And once you open the document, no protected view.
VBA engine loads automatically,
actually, before the document is fully loaded.
And VBA referencing occurs eventually, just like before.
So, we can actually spot a difference in here.
There's a gap between a user and a sandbox.

And just a few notes on protected view.
So, most people think that protected view is for code,
